bestBHT.bht: In this parable, the householder's equal payment to all workers illustrates the calculating and mercenary spirit prevalent among the servants of Christ. Those who worked longer expected more, but their false hopes were shattered when they received only what they had agreed upon. The parable serves to debunk the notion that the first group of workers should always be preferred and teaches a valuable lesson about fairness and justice in the kingdom of God.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: This is that calculating, mercenary spirit.
This parable was designed once for all to put down.
Albert Barnes: They supposed that they should have received more - They had worked longer - they had been in the heat...
They supposed that it was his intention to pay them, not according to contract, but according to the time of the labor.
Marvin Vincent: Every man a penny [το ανα δηναριον] . Lit., the sum amounting in each case to a penny; or a penny apiece. Ana is distributive. Wyc., each one by himself a penny.
Archibald T. Robertson: Every man a penny (ανα δηναριον κα αυτο). Literally, 'themselves also a denarius apiece.'"
Bruce asks if this householder was a humorist when he began to pay off the last first and paid each one a denarius according to agreement."
False hopes had been raised in those who came first who got only what they had agreed to receive.
John Gill: They supposed, or 'hoped',... that they should have received more.
John Wesley: The first supposed they should have received more — Probably the first here may mean the Jews, who supposed they should always be preferred before the Gentiles.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, we see a parable that exposes the calculating and mercenary spirit found among the servants of Christ. The householder pays each worker a denarius, causing the first to be upset because they had worked longer and were expecting more. However, the parable was designed to debunk false hopes and put down this sense of entitlement. The first group of workers had erroneously believed that they would always be preferred over others, a notion that is shattered by the householder's fair and just payment to all.

In this parable, a calculating and mercenary spirit is exposed among the servants of Christ. The first group of workers, expecting more due to their longer labor, were disappointed when paid an equal amount. False hopes had been raised in them, as they believed they would always be preferred. However, this parable was designed to dismantle such entitlement and teach a valuable lesson about fair and just treatment. The householder's payment to all workers equally challenges the notion of preferential treatment and upends their expectations.

In this parable, the householder's equal payment to all workers illustrates the calculating and mercenary spirit prevalent among the servants of Christ. Those who worked longer expected more, but their false hopes were shattered when they received only what they had agreed upon. The parable serves to debunk the notion that the first group of workers should always be preferred and teaches a valuable lesson about fairness and justice in the kingdom of God.

In this parable, the householder's equal payment of a denarius to each worker addresses the calculating and mercenary spirit found among the servants of Christ. The first group of workers, expecting more due to their longer labor, had false hopes and believed they should always be preferred. However, the parable was designed to debunk these false expectations and emphasize fairness and justice. The householder's payment to all workers equally challenges the notion of preferential treatment and teaches an important lesson about the kingdom of God.

In this parable, the householder's equal payment of a denarius to each worker challenges the calculating and mercenary spirit among the servants of Christ. Though the first group of workers expected more due to their longer labor, the parable debunks their false hopes and teaches a lesson about fairness and justice. By paying all workers equally, the householder dismantles the notion of preferential treatment and emphasizes that in the kingdom of God, everyone is treated with equity.
